bricklayers:craftinginfo-coloredclay-tex:
Colored Pottery

This guide will teach you how to create pottery out of colored clay or fine porcelain.

Needed Resources

Start by crafting colored clay. You will need blue or fire clay as a basis, these can be found throughout the world. The rest of the ingredients will vary according to the color you want to create. As an example, light clay needs lime, while green clay needs either lime + copper or olivine or Viridian.

You will need a pulverizer and a quern to create the coloring ingredients. Having an automated quern greatly helps.

Porcelain

Porcelain is crafted according to Spode's formulation:
12 parts bone ash, 8 parts finely ground granite and 7 parts light clay.

For colored porcelain, 3 light clay are replaced by colored clay of the desired color.

Pottery and Items

You can form various pottery items or bricks out of colored clay or porcelain, these all need to be fired in a pit kiln before being used.

Biscuit Porcelain

Unglazed porcelain items and blocks are called biscuit porcelain. They have a fine, evenly colored and silky smooth surface. Great for statues and decoration!

Hardened Clay & Porcelain

Heating 8 pieces of clay or porcelain in a fire will result in a hardened clay or biscuit porcelain block. These can be sawed in half, a great way to save material while chiseling.

Note

Colored clay items can only be glazed with salt.

bricklayers:craftinginfo-coloredglass-te:
Colored Glass

This guide will teach you how to create colored glass and its variants like milky, smoky, dark, quartz or even opaque glass.
The process might seem daunting at first, but follow this guide and the recipes in the handbook and soon you too will be able to decorate your build with some brilliantly colored glass!

Required Resources

You will need many different resources, most notably:
- quartz chunks
- fire clay for fire clay bricks
- lead ore chunks or borax
- lime
- for milky glass: cassiterite ore or boneash
- different metal ore chunks depending on the desired color.

To create the coloring ingredients, you will need a pulverizer and a quern. Having automated machinery greatly helps!

Crafting Ingredients

In a few cases quartz or crystals can be smelted directly into glass blocks.
Most colored variants, and most special glass types like dark, smoky, quartz, milky and opaque glass need to be smelted from a mixture of dry ingredients called a glass batch. Here is an example: blue glass batch. The process follows these steps:

- Create ground frit in your color of choice, for example blue frit
- Craft a glass batch by mixing frit, sand, lime, quartz and either lead oxide or borax together

For special glass variants like milky glass, craft the right glass batch from your plain glass batch by adding ingredients like powdered tin oxide or powdered coal.

Smelting Glass

To smelt glass you will need to build one or more bloomery bases and chimneys from fire clay bricks.
Add the glass batch to the bloomery, fill in enough fuel and light the bloomery. Once the smelting process is done, break the bloomery apart and recover the glass blocks.

You can use a saw to cut the glass blocks in half, and even chisel them to your liking.

Recycling

To turn glass blocks or slabs back into raw materials, use a hammer or pickaxe together with the glass in your crafting grid.

bricklayers:craftinginfo-glazedceramics-:
Glazed Ceramics

Practicality and art combined into masterpieces.

This will be your guide to become a master glazer.

Glazing ceramics is a whole new process that will take quite a few of your resources, including some time and thought. In turn you will be rewarded with wonderful items to decorate, show off, or trade.

Advice for Beginners
Do not be discouraged by the complexity!
Follow this guide step by step, and you will succeed.
Start small: For your first piece choose:
- a clear glazing (this needs less resources)
- copper based colors are cheap and easy
- Aim for 30 litre glazing (enough for one planter, one flowerpot and some bowls)

If you feel adventurous: bring copper ore chunks and choose one of green, green-blue or blue
And last but not least: please bring time and patience.

Needed Machinery

You will need all of the following:
- a pulverizer
- a quern
- a few barrels and at least one bucket
- a water source
- a fireplace
- lots of high-temperature fuel: charcoal, brown coal or black coal

Having an automated quern and multiple fireplaces greatly helps.

Required Resources

You will need quite a lot of the following:
- quartz chunks
- clay (blue or fire)
- lead ore chunks or borax
- lime
- cassiterite ore chunks (for milky glazings)
- some copper ore chunks (if you choose green, blue or green-blue as color)
- other ores for different colors (see Colors via Frit below).

Overview

The process involves the following steps, some of these can be done in advance or in parallel to others:
- Mix clay with water to create a clay slurry
- Create a glazing base, either clear or milky
- Create one or more Frit (a colored powder). See below for details.
- Add the powdered Frit to the glazing base
- Let the colored glazing rest for 2 days (48 hours)
- Glaze your ceramics in a barrel
- Fire your glazed items

Optionally you can add a pattern - see below for details.

The result will be a rare and wonderful piece of art! \o/

Glazing Items

Glazing items in a barrel needs a certain surplus amount of glazing liquid to evenly coat the workpiece. This will limit the amount of pieces you can coat in one step in a barrel.

The following table lists the amount of glazing needed and used up for the various items:

- Planter: uses 12 litres
- Flowerpot: uses 6 litres
- Bowl: uses 3 litres
- Tile: uses 3 litres
- Brick: uses 2 litres
- Mug: uses 1 litres

Colors via Frit

To colorize your glazing, you need to prepare a mixture called Frit. It consists of 8 parts of various dry powders. Frit can be used to color both glazes and glass batches to create colored glass. To prepare frit you need:

- crush ingredients with a pulverizer
- grind the result into fine powders with a quern
- Combine the dry powders
- sinter (half-bake) the mix
- grind the baked frit again into ground frit

The ingredients are always:
- 4 parts powdered quartz
- 1 part lime
- 1 part powdered lead oxide or powdered borax
- 2 varying parts of coloring ingredients.
After mixing everything together, you need to sinter (bake) it, then grind the result into a very fine powder with the quern. The resulting powder can then be added to the glazing base for the final, colored glazing solution.

Rare Colors

There are a lot of color options available, but some of them require unique or rare ingredients like ilmenite, or even the prized cinnabar or Lapis lazuli. The resulting colors are very vibrant and beautiful, though.

Adding Patterns

To add a pattern to a glazed item, follow these steps:

- form a pattern stamp from clay
- bake it
- use beeswax the protect the topside
- fill the waxed pattern with clear brown glaze
- apply the pattern with the color onto your workpiece

After stamping the pattern onto your workpiece, you need to bake the piece once more, and finally, your work is done! \o/

Note:If you are not satisfied with the pattern, you can wash it off in a barrel of limewater. You need to do this before you bake it in!
